Are you being asked to provide your social insurance number (SIN) when applying to rent a property or negotiating a lease?

If a property management company refuses to complete the application process unless you provide your SIN, ask to speak to the person in charge. Bottom line: Your SIN is confidential and should only be requested and used for income reporting purposes.

Learn more about protecting your SIN: http://ow.ly/K37l303bzgJ

#Students: Do you know which services are included in your tuition fees?

Knowing what you’re paying for can help you make smart money decisions. For example, tuition often includes fees for health and dental insurance, so if you’re already covered by similar insurance, you can save a few hundred dollars each school year by opting out. But don’t wait as there is often a cut-off for applying for these exclusions.

Check out these other money saving tips for students: http://ow.ly/fJK7303bwIj

Don’t you hate shopping for an item advertised as “on sale” to find it’s already sold out? 

If the bargain you seek is out of stock, ask for a rain check. This will allow you to get the deal once the item has been re-stocked.

If a rain check is not offered and the seller cannot prove that the item was reasonably stocked or that it sold out due to reasons they were not able to control, it could be considered bait and switch selling—which is illegal.

Learn more: http://ow.ly/uats3034uYN
